text: Hello everyone! Question: We have a package that loads some very specific type of files (SBML, the systems biology markup) and we would like to "add" it to the JuliaIO organization ( <https://github.com/JuliaIO> ), partly because it would make it a bit more findable for the others, and partly because it would be great to use the possible heap of community feedback on standards and so. Is there a recommended way to do that?

elements.text: Hello everyone! Question: We have a package that loads some very specific type of files (SBML, the systems biology markup) and we would like to "add" it to the JuliaIO organization (

), partly because it would make it a bit more findable for the others, and partly because it would be great to use the possible heap of community feedback on standards and so. Is there a recommended way to do that?

text: <@U680THK2S> friendly reminder in case you missed this :grin:

elements.text: friendly reminder in case you missed this

text: Ah yes I did, thanks. In general, my philosophy on adding packages to organizations is that it makes sense when a critical mass of org members will be involved in maintenance/development, and when a package falls within the perceived scope of the organization. In this case, I would say that SBML seems fairly niche compared to the other repositories in JuliaIO, and I wouldn't anticipate that most of the members would be involved. That said, I'm just one person with one set of opinions, so I'd be happy to hear from/discuss with other JuliaIO folks.

text: as a datapoint, I can add that `FITSIO.jl` is a package to read/write files in a specific file format commonly used in astronomy, and it's under the JuliaAstro organisation: <https://github.com/JuliaAstro/FITSIO.jl>
